title: How to start to start teaching science to my 4 years old kid? Can anyone recommend a good science website for kids - Quora

response.answer_text: Wait. You want to allow children to learn in a learner-centered environment. To do this, you need to change the way you view education. You, as parent-teacher, are a guide. Do not teach as the authority. Instead, listen to your child’s thoughts and questions, and respond to these. Children are natural scientists. They ask questions and try to fit the answers into a hypothesis. Why are trees green?Why is the sky blue?How do trees grow?Where is the sun at night?Why, when I get into the bathtub, does the water rise?What are those floaty things I see when the sun’s rays shine through my window?Which is heavier, a pound of feathers or a pound of lead?So, the research needed to answer these questions is research for you to do, and then it is your job to explain what you learned to answer your child's questions. There is no website for you to accomplish the task of educating your child in all subjects of interest relating to science. When questions are beyond your ken to answer, find an expert.  When my child was three, he was in pre-school. He knew all things were made of matter, and matter was made of atoms. And then he asked a question which I could not answer: What is the difference between a photon and an electron?I didn’t know. I could not find an answer (pre-internet). So I telephoned UCLA’s physics department and asked if someone could explain it to me. They did. A grad student ended up coming over to join us for a few dinners (plus pay) and answered our questions in a way that satisfied my child’s desire to understand more than I could teach. He has been an autodidact ever since. Ditto, his sister. And, ditto, their mother.

4 year olds should play…. there is science on the playground, in the bathtub, in the kitchen…. etc…. kids this young also should not be exposed to screens… read the recommendations of the American Academy of Pediatrics. Children learn through experience, not TV or screens… and again… let kids be kids.. they should play… they have plenty of time to formally learn about science….

The new “Cosmos” series by Neil DeGrasse Tyson has made my son an avid fan of cosmology and science. His birthday presents included a Cosmos hoodie and a science kit, and he was ecstatic. You should watch it together, in order to explain some of the more complicated parts, and if you don’t know a particular answer, search for it online together. At least, that’s how it worked for me.

Teach your 4 year old how to look at the world around her. Get a good magnifying glass and start exploring with it. Go to any good science museum or nature center. Go often. Science at this age is about being interested in the world. Help her to discover how things work. Help her ask questions about the world, and think about answers. Don’t work at preparing her for science courses—work at getting her interested when she takes those classes.
Let them learn on their own time. Four year olds are already learning bazillion things a day, more than an adult can comprehend, so forcing more on top of that isn’t necessarily a good thing.
http://Jw.org has a lot of science and nature articles. Just put a subject into the search bar.
